title: Active Inference Framework
description: Comprehensive introduction to the Active Inference framework as a theory of behavior and brain function.
learning_objectives: Understand the basic components of Active Inference
Explain how perception and action are unified in Active Inference
Apply Active Inference to simple decision-making problems
Connect Active Inference to the Free Energy Principle

content.overview: Active Inference is a framework that explains behavior as the process of minimizing expected free energy. It unifies perception, action, and planning under a single principle: agents act to confirm their predictions about the world.

core_principle.expected_free_energy: G(π) = ∑_τ E_Q[log Q(π) - log P(o_τ, s_τ)]
core_principle.interpretation: Expected free energy combines epistemic and pragmatic value
core_principle.policy_selection: Choose policies that minimize expected free energy
core_principle.unified_framework: Perception and action both minimize free energy

key_components.description: Internal model of how observations are generated
key_components.role: Predicts sensory input and outcomes of actions

key_components.description: Approximate posterior beliefs about hidden states
Sequences of actions or control states
key_components.role: Options for how to act in the world

perception_action_cycle.perception: Infer hidden states from sensory input (minimize variational free energy)
perception_action_cycle.planning: Evaluate policies by expected free energy
perception_action_cycle.action: Select and execute policy with minimal expected free energy
perception_action_cycle.learning: Update generative model based on outcomes

expected_free_energy_decomposition.policy_evaluation: Lower expected free energy = better policy

examples.name: Foraging Behavior
examples.description: Animal searching for food in an environment with uncertain resource locations
examples.preferences: Prior beliefs favoring states with high food probability
examples.policies: Movement sequences that maximize information about food locations
examples.expected_free_energy: G(π) = E[surprise - log P(food_found)] - reduces when food is located
examples.active_inference_mechanism: Animal moves to locations that minimize uncertainty about food presence
examples.empirical_evidence: Optimal foraging theory predicts information-seeking behavior

examples.name: Visual Search
examples.description: Human searching for a target object in a cluttered visual scene
examples.preferences: Prior beliefs about likely target locations based on context
examples.policies: Saccade sequences that efficiently reduce uncertainty about target location
examples.expected_free_energy: G(π) = E[visual_uncertainty - log P(target_found)] - minimized through strategic eye movements
examples.active_inference_mechanism: Eyes move to locations that maximize information gain about target presence
examples.neural_correlates: Lateral intraparietal area (LIP) encodes expected free energy of saccades

examples.name: Social Interaction
examples.description: Two agents communicating to achieve mutual understanding
examples.preferences: Prior beliefs about cooperative social norms and shared goals
examples.policies: Utterance sequences that minimize uncertainty about partner's intentions
examples.expected_free_energy: G(π) = E[social_uncertainty - log P(mutual_understanding)] - reduced through clarification questions
examples.active_inference_mechanism: Agents ask questions that resolve ambiguity about each other's mental states
examples.theory_of_mind_aspect: Recursive belief modeling: 'I believe you believe I want X'

examples.name: Robot Navigation
examples.description: Autonomous robot navigating to a goal location in unknown environment
examples.preferences: Prior beliefs about goal location and safety constraints
examples.policies: Movement sequences that balance goal-directed action with exploration
examples.active_inference_mechanism: Robot explores areas that reduce uncertainty about optimal path to goal
examples.practical_implementation: Used in robotics for simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM)

examples.name: Medical Diagnosis
examples.description: Physician diagnosing patient condition based on symptoms and tests
examples.preferences: Prior beliefs about disease prevalence and treatment effectiveness
examples.policies: Test sequences that efficiently narrow down possible diagnoses
examples.expected_free_energy: G(π) = E[diagnostic_uncertainty - log P(correct_diagnosis)] - minimizes unnecessary tests
examples.active_inference_mechanism: Physician orders tests that provide maximum information about disease state
examples.clinical_benefit: Reduces diagnostic uncertainty while minimizing patient burden

planning_and_control.policy_space: Set of all possible action sequences over future time horizon τ
planning_and_control.tree_search: Forward simulation of policy consequences using generative model
planning_and_control.stochastic_policies: Probabilistic action selection based on expected free energy minimization
planning_and_control.habitual_behavior: Cached policies for familiar situations to reduce computational load
planning_and_control.temporal_horizon: Planning depth - how far into the future to evaluate consequences
planning_and_control.policy_evaluation: Compute expected free energy G(π) for each candidate policy π
planning_and_control.action_selection: Select policy with minimal expected free energy using softmax or argmin
planning_and_control.online_planning: Real-time policy adaptation based on current observations
planning_and_control.hierarchical_policies: Multi-scale action sequences from high-level goals to motor commands
planning_and_control.robust_control: Policies that perform well under model uncertainty and environmental changes

connections_to_neuroscience.dopamine: Encodes prediction errors and expected free energy gradients - phasic dopamine signals policy improvement
connections_to_neuroscience.prefrontal_cortex: Planning and policy evaluation - dorsolateral PFC maintains multiple policy representations
connections_to_neuroscience.basal_ganglia: Action selection and policy switching - direct and indirect pathways implement policy competition
connections_to_neuroscience.anterior_cingulate: Conflict monitoring and uncertainty - ACC tracks expected free energy and prediction errors
connections_to_neuroscience.posterior_cingulate: Scene construction and epistemic foraging - PCC builds coherent internal models
connections_to_neuroscience.hippocampus: Episodic memory and model updating - hippocampus stores and retrieves generative model parameters
connections_to_neuroscience.cerebellum: Motor control and precision optimization - cerebellum implements hierarchical motor policies
connections_to_neuroscience.temporal_cortex: Perceptual inference and category learning - temporal areas perform variational inference on sensory inputs
connections_to_neuroscience.predictive_coding_hierarchy: Hierarchical message passing in cortical columns implements variational inference
connections_to_neuroscience.attention_networks: Modulate precision weights - attention networks control the relative influence of prediction errors
connections_to_neuroscience.default_mode_network: Internal simulation and policy evaluation - DMN simulates future policy consequences
connections_to_neuroscience.salience_network: Uncertainty detection and inference mode switching - SN detects when beliefs need updating
connections_to_neuroscience.neuromodulators: Global precision control - acetylcholine, noradrenaline modulate prediction error gain
connections_to_neuroscience.synaptic_plasticity: Learning and model updating - spike-timing dependent plasticity implements belief updating

interactive_exercises.description: Simulate simple Active Inference agent navigating a grid world to find hidden rewards
interactive_exercises.implementation_notes: Use Python with NumPy - implement generative model, policy evaluation, action selection

interactive_exercises.description: Calculate expected free energy G(π) for different policies in a decision problem
steps: Rank policies by expected free energy

interactive_exercises.description: Interactive demonstration of prediction error minimization in perception
Explore the free energy landscape for different policies and environments
Multi-agent game demonstrating theory of mind and social Active Inference
learning_objectives: Apply Active Inference to social settings

interactive_exercises.description: Explore how Active Inference might be implemented in neural circuits

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference is only about motor control
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference explains all adaptive behavior, including perception, learning, and decision-making. The same principle that drives action selection also drives perceptual inference and belief updating.
common_misconceptions.evidence: Active Inference unifies perception and action under free energy minimization - perception minimizes variational free energy while action minimizes expected free energy.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference requires perfect knowledge of the world
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference works with approximate generative models and handles uncertainty explicitly. It uses Bayesian inference to update beliefs and makes optimal decisions under uncertainty.
common_misconceptions.evidence: The framework explicitly models uncertainty through probability distributions and uses variational inference for tractable approximate inference.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Expected free energy is the same as traditional reward functions
common_misconceptions.clarification: Expected free energy combines extrinsic rewards (pragmatic value) with information gain (epistemic value), naturally balancing exploration and exploitation without separate mechanisms.
common_misconceptions.evidence: G(π) = E[surprise - log P(preferences)] includes both terms: surprise minimization drives exploration while preference satisfaction drives exploitation.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference is the same as reinforcement learning
common_misconceptions.clarification: While both involve learning and decision-making, Active Inference uses generative models and free energy minimization, while RL uses reward functions and value functions. Active Inference naturally includes curiosity-driven exploration.
common_misconceptions.evidence: Active Inference optimizes expected free energy G(π), which includes epistemic affordance terms that RL typically adds separately through bonus rewards.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference only applies to biological systems
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference provides a general framework for any adaptive system, including robots, AI agents, and engineered systems. It has been successfully applied to autonomous vehicles, game-playing agents, and industrial control systems.
common_misconceptions.evidence: Active Inference has been implemented in robotics for navigation and manipulation, in AI for safe decision-making, and in economics for modeling bounded rationality.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference is computationally intractable for real applications
common_misconceptions.clarification: While the full theory involves complex computations, practical approximations using variational inference, sampling methods, and hierarchical models make it computationally feasible for real-time applications.
common_misconceptions.evidence: Successful implementations exist using MCMC sampling, variational approximations, and neural network implementations that run in real-time on standard hardware.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference assumes rational agents with perfect self-knowledge
common_misconceptions.clarification: Active Inference models bounded rationality and meta-cognitive limitations. Agents can have incorrect models of themselves and others, and the framework explains how they learn and adapt these models.
common_misconceptions.evidence: The framework includes hierarchical generative models that can represent beliefs about beliefs (theory of mind) and supports model updating through experience.

common_misconceptions.misconception: Active Inference is just predictive coding with actions
common_misconceptions.clarification: While predictive coding implements perceptual inference in Active Inference, the framework extends to action, learning, and decision-making. Predictive coding is one neural implementation, but Active Inference is the broader theory.
common_misconceptions.evidence: Active Inference includes policy selection, expected free energy minimization, and multi-agent interactions that go beyond predictive coding's focus on perception.

further_reading.title: Active Inference: The Free Energy Principle in Mind, Brain, and Behavior
further_reading.author: Thomas Parr, Giovanni Pezzulo, Karl Friston
further_reading.description: Comprehensive book covering the full Active Inference framework with mathematical foundations and applications

further_reading.title: Planning and Navigation as Active Inference
further_reading.author: Karl Friston et al.
further_reading.description: Seminal paper introducing the Active Inference framework for planning and action

further_reading.title: Active Inference and Epistemic Value in Brain Physiology
further_reading.author: Karl Friston et al.
further_reading.description: Recent advances in understanding epistemic foraging and information-seeking behavior in the brain

further_reading.title: Active Inference in Robotics: A Survey
further_reading.author: Pablo Lanillos et al.
further_reading.description: Comprehensive review of Active Inference applications in autonomous robotics and control

further_reading.title: Scaling Active Inference
further_reading.author: Beren Millidge et al.
further_reading.description: Practical methods for implementing Active Inference in large-scale systems and neural networks

further_reading.title: Active Inference and Consciousness
further_reading.author: Karl Friston et al.
further_reading.description: Theoretical exploration of consciousness through the lens of Active Inference

further_reading.title: A Tutorial on Active Inference
further_reading.author: Christopher Buckley et al.
further_reading.description: Accessible introduction with worked examples and practical implementations

further_reading.title: Active Inference for Discrete State-Space Models
further_reading.author: Lancelot Da Costa et al.
further_reading.description: Practical guide to implementing Active Inference in discrete domains

further_reading.title: The Free Energy Principle for Action and Perception: A Mathematical Review
further_reading.author: Christopher Buckley et al.
further_reading.description: Rigorous mathematical treatment of the Free Energy Principle foundations

further_reading.title: Active Inference and the Anatomy of oculomotion
further_reading.author: Karl Friston et al.
further_reading.description: Application of Active Inference to eye movement control and visual attention
